title: The Stranglers
text:
{{short description|English rock band}}
{{About|a punk rock band|the true crime podcast|Stranglers (podcast)}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2020}}
{{Use British English|date=May 2013}}
{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->
| name            = The Stranglers
| image           = The Stranglers (band).JPG
| alt             = 
| caption         = The Stranglers performing in Chicago in 2013
| landscape       = yes
| background      = group_or_band
| origin          = [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], England
| genre           = {{hlist|[[Punk rock]]<ref>{{cite news |first=Garth |last=Cartwright |title=Dave Greenfield: Keyboardist Who Defined the Sound of the Stranglers |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=17 May 2020 |access-date=5 June 2021 |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/dave-greenfield-death-coronavirus-stranglers-keyboardist-punk-age-cause-a9502241.html?amp?}}</ref>|[[Pub rock (United Kingdom)|pub rock]]<ref name="Hughes">{{cite web 
|first=Rob |last=Hughes |access-date=5 June 2021
|url=https://www.loudersound.com/amp/features/buyers-guide-the-stranglers |title=The Stranglers: A Guide to Their Best Album |website=[[Louder Sound]] |date=6 May 2020 }}</ref>|[[new wave music|new wave]]<ref name="Hughes"/>|[[post-punk]]}}
| years_active    = {{Start date|1974}}–present
| label           = {{hlist|[[United Artists Records|United Artists]]|[[A&M Records|A&M]]|[[Liberty Records|Liberty]]|[[EMI]]|[[Epic Records|Epic]]|[[Stiff Records|Stiff]]|[[Castle Communications]]}}
| website         = {{URL|http://www.thestranglers.co.uk/}}
| current_members = 
* [[Jean-Jacques Burnel]]
* [[Baz Warne]]
* [[Jim Macaulay]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Dark Matters |url=https://stranglers.tmstor.es/product/79632 |website=Stranglers Official Online Store |publisher=TM Stores |access-date=24 August 2021|quote="Surviving Stranglers band members, JJ Burnel, Baz Warne and newest member Jim Macaulay completed Dark Matters remotely during lockdowns, making it their first album since 2012."}}</ref>
* [[Rialto_(band)|Toby Hounsham]]
| past_members    = 
* [[Jet Black]]<ref name=robbdarkmatters>{{cite web |last1=Robb |first1=John |title=The Stranglers: Dark Matters – album review |url=https://louderthanwar.com/the-stranglers-dark-matters/ |website=Louder Than War |date=11 August 2021 |access-date=25 August 2021|quote="It’s been a long time since we heard any new material and the album has been overshadowed by the death of core band member Dave Greenfield and his genius keys, and the final retirement of the great Jet Black but the record has been worth the wait. "}}</ref>
* [[Hugh Cornwell]]
* [[Hans Wärmling]]
* [[Dave Greenfield]]
* [[John Ellis (guitarist)|John Ellis]]
* [[Paul Roberts (musician)|Paul Roberts]]
}}

'''The Stranglers''' are an English rock band who emerged via the [[punk rock]] scene. Scoring 23 [[UK top 40]] singles and 19 UK top 40 albums to date in a career spanning five decades, the Stranglers are one of the longest-surviving bands to have originated in the UK punk scene.

Formed as the Guildford Stranglers in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], in early 1974,{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=23}} they originally built a following within the mid-1970s [[Pub rock (United Kingdom)|pub rock]] scene. While their aggressive, no-compromise attitude had them identified by the media with the emerging UK [[punk rock]] scene that followed, their idiosyncratic approach rarely followed any single [[musical genre]], and the group went on to explore a variety of musical styles, from [[new wave music|new wave]], [[art rock]] and [[gothic rock]] through the [[sophisti-pop]] of some of their 1980s output. They had major mainstream success with their 1982 single "[[Golden Brown]]". Their other hits include "[[No More Heroes (The Stranglers song)|No More Heroes]]", "[[Peaches (The Stranglers song)|Peaches]]", "[[Always the Sun]]", "[[Skin Deep (The Stranglers song)|Skin Deep]]" and "[[Big Thing Coming]]".

The Stranglers' early sound was driven by [[Jean-Jacques Burnel]]'s melodic bass, but also gave prominence to [[Dave Greenfield]]'s keyboards. 
Their early music was also characterised by the growling vocals and sometimes [[Misanthropy|misanthropic]] lyrics of both Burnel and [[Hugh Cornwell]].<ref>{{Citation
| last  = Hasted
| first = Nick
| date  = 6 November 2007
| title = The Stranglers, Roundhouse, London
| work = [[The Independent]]
| url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/the-stranglers-roundhouse-london-399216.html
}}</ref> Over time, their output gradually grew more refined and sophisticated. Summing up their contribution to popular music, critic Dave Thompson later wrote: "From bad-mannered [[yobbo|yobs]] to purveyors of supreme pop delicacies, the group was responsible for music that may have been ugly and might have been crude – but it was never, ever boring."<ref>{{cite web
| url = {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p5542/biography|pure_url=yes}}
| title = Biography
| access-date = 25 May 2008
| last = Thompson
| first = Dave
| format = DLL
| work=The Stranglers
| publisher=allmusic
}}</ref>

Keyboard player Dave Greenfield died on 3 May 2020 after contracting [[COVID-19]] while receiving treatment for a heart ailment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestranglers.co.uk/?p=16131|title=Stranglers Official Site › David Paul Greenfield (29/3/49-3/5/20)|website=www.thestranglers.co.uk}}</ref> The remaining band members completed a new album recorded with Greenfield, ''[[Dark Matters (The Stranglers album)|Dark Matters]]'' following his death and confirmed that they would proceed with their "Final Full UK Tour", initially announced in January 2020, in his honour.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Stranglers Official Site › UK tour autumn/winter 2020|url=http://www.thestranglers.co.uk/?p=16044|access-date=2020-09-15|website=www.thestranglers.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestranglers.co.uk/?p=16169/|title=Stranglers Official Site › Full Final UK Tour And Album Update|website=www.thestranglers.co.uk}}</ref>

==History==
===Formation and mainstream success (1974–1979)===
Before forming the band, "[[Jet Black]]" (real name Brian Duffy) was in his mid-30s. A successful businessman, Black at one point owned a fleet of ice cream vans,<ref>[https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-137712305 Western Mail (Cardiff, Wales)] – The Stranglers.(News)</ref> and later ran "The Jackpot",<ref>[http://www.getreading.co.uk/entertainment/music/s/2077227_the_stranglers_prepare_for_weyfest The Stranglers prepare for Weyfest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904072001/http://www.getreading.co.uk/entertainment/music/s/2077227_the_stranglers_prepare_for_weyfest |date=4 September 2010 }} – GetReading.co.uk</ref> a Guildford [[Licensing laws of the United Kingdom#Off-licence|off-licence]] that would serve as the base for the early Stranglers.<ref>[http://www.virginradio.co.uk/music/artists/the_stranglers/ Virgin Radio] – Stranglers biography</ref><ref>[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-21143906_ITM TRIBUTE – THE STRANGLERS: The stranglers' timeline.(Chronology)] – Music Week</ref> Black had also been a semi-professional drummer in the late 1950s and early 1960s; after attaining a degree of financial stability due to his business successes, by 1974 he decided to return to drumming, and to assemble a band. The Stranglers came to be an influential band in the British punk and new wave scene of the mid-70s. Black drove the ice cream vans that would serve as the Stranglers' early tour buses.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/mar/12/stranglers-40-years-fights-drugs-ufos The Stranglers on 40 years of fights, drugs, UFOs and 'doing all the wrong things'] - ''The Guardian''. 12 March 2014. Retrieved 17 September 2021.</ref>

The group that eventually formed between 1974 and 1975 was originally named the Guildford Stranglers,  but they soon dropped the geographical prefix and the name, ''The Stranglers'', was registered as a business on 11 September 1974 by Black.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=23}}<ref>{{cite web |title='74-'14: Forty years in photos-part 1 |url=http://www.thestranglers.co.uk/?p=10457 |website=Stranglers Official Site |access-date=25 June 2020}}</ref> The other original personnel were bass player/vocalist [[Jean-Jacques Burnel]], guitarist/vocalist [[Hugh Cornwell]] and keyboardist/guitarist [[Hans Wärmling]], who was replaced by keyboardist [[Dave Greenfield]] within a year.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=28}} None of the band came from the Guildford area apart from Burnel, who was originally from [[Notting Hill]] but moved to [[Godalming]] during his childhood. Black is from [[Ilford]], Cornwell from [[Kentish Town]] and Greenfield from [[Brighton]], while Wärmling came from [[Gothenburg]] and returned there after leaving the band.

Cornwell was a [[blues]] musician before forming the band and had briefly been a bandmate of [[Richard Thompson (musician)|Richard Thompson]],{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=11}} Burnel had been a classical guitarist who had performed with symphony orchestras,{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=16}} Black's musical background was as a jazz drummer,{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=7}} and Dave Greenfield had played at military bases in Germany.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=30}} Their early influences included pre-punk [[psychedelic rock]] bands such as [[the Doors]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/jean-jacques-burnel-of-the-stranglers-on-the-songs-that-changed-his-life/U3DVHIARBZCDIPTUVQ4WF7EJZI/ |date=13 February 2020  |title=Jean-Jacques Burnel of the Stranglers on the Songs That Changed His Life |website=Nzherald.co.nz |accessdate=17 March 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/4rhj |title=Music – Review of the Stranglers – Rattus Norvegicus |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |access-date=17 March 2021}}</ref> and [[the Music Machine]].

From 1976 the Stranglers became associated with the burgeoning punk rock movement, due in part to their opening for the first British tours of American punks [[the Ramones]] and [[Patti Smith]].{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=46}}{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=49}} Notwithstanding this association, some of the movement's champions in the British musical press viewed the band with suspicion on account of their age and musical virtuosity and the intellectual bent of some of their lyrics. However, Burnel was quoted saying, "I thought of myself as part of punk at the time because we were inhabiting the same flora and fauna ... I would like to think the Stranglers were more punk plus and then some."<ref name="punk77-Pt2">{{cite web
| url = http://www.punk77.co.uk/groups/stranglersjjburnelin052.htm
| title = JJ Burnel Stranglers Interview Pt2 – Punk Rock
| access-date = 25 March 2008
| year = 2005
| publisher=Punk77
}}</ref>

The band's early albums, ''[[Rattus Norvegicus (album)|Rattus Norvegicus]]'', ''[[No More Heroes (album)|No More Heroes]]'' and ''[[Black and White (The Stranglers album)|Black and White]]'', all released within a period of 13 months, were highly successful with the record-buying public and singles such as "[[Peaches (The Stranglers song)|Peaches]]", "[[Something Better Change (song)|Something Better Change]]" and  "[[No More Heroes (song)|No More Heroes]]" became instant punk classics. Meanwhile, the band received a mixed reception from some critics because of their apparent sexist and racist innuendo. However, critic Dave Thompson argued that such criticism was oblivious to the satire and irony in the band's music, writing: "the Stranglers themselves revelled in an almost [[Monty Python]]-esque grasp of [[surreal humour|absurd]]ity (and, in particular, the absurdities of modern 'men's talk')."<ref>
{{cite web
| url = {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p5542/biography|pure_url=yes}}
| title = The Stranglers' biography at ''allmusic.com''
| author=Thompson, Dave
| access-date = 10 September 2006
}}</ref>
These albums went on to build a strong fan-following, but the group's confrontational attitude towards the press was increasingly problematic and triggered a severe backlash when Burnel, a martial arts enthusiast, punched music journalist [[Jon Savage]] during a promotional event.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=99}}

In February 1978 the Stranglers began a mini-tour, playing three secret pub gigs as a thank-you to those venues and their landlords for their support during the band's rise to success. The first was at The Duke of Lancaster in [[New Barnet]] on Valentine's Day,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestranglers.net/?p=3045 |title=Stranglers Official Site |publisher=Stranglers.net |access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref> with further performances at The Red Cow, [[Hammersmith]], and The Nashville Rooms, [[West Kensington]], in early September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xulucomics.com/Live.html |title=Stranglers Live Performances 1974–1990 |publisher=Xulucomics.com |date=12 August 1990 |access-date=30 December 2011}}</ref>

During their appearance at the [[University of Surrey]] on the BBC TV programme ''[[Rock Goes to College]]'' on 19 October 1978, the group walked off stage because an agreement to make tickets available to non-university students had not been honoured.<ref name="rgtc">{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.sewer.uklinux.net/rgtc.php
 |title       = The Stranglers: Rock Goes To College
 |publisher   = Swewr.uklinux.net
 |access-date  = 21 April 2006
 |url-status     = dead
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210204/http://www.sewer.uklinux.net/rgtc.php
 |archive-date = 30 September 2007
 |df          = dmy-all
}}</ref>

In the later half of the 1970s, the Stranglers toured Japan twice, joining the alternative music scene of Tokyo, which was evolving from the punk sound of Kyoto-based band Murahachibu (村八分, ''Ostracism''), whose music influence spread to Tokyo in 1971. The Stranglers were the only foreign band to take part in a landmark scene focused around S-KEN Studio in [[Roppongi]], and The Loft venues in [[Shinjuku]] and [[Shimokitazawa]] from 1977 to 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bounce.com/article/article.php/2733 |title=マガジン |publisher=Bounce.com |access-date=4 July 2011}}</ref> The scene included bands such as [[Friction (band)|Friction]], and they became friends with the band, Red Lizard, who they invited back to London, where the band became known as Lizard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000042455 |title=V.A.（PUNK） : ＜パンクロックの封印を解く＞"東京ロッカーズ"の全貌に迫る『ROCKERS[完全版]』 / BARKS ニュース |publisher={{Interlanguage link multi|Barks.jp|2=ja|3=BARKS|preserve=1}} |access-date=4 July 2011}}</ref> In 1979, while still in Japan, Burnel also became close friends with Keith, co-founder and drummer for [[ARB (band)|ARB]]. At the end of 1983, ARB's bassist was imprisoned, leaving the band with a problem for their forthcoming tour. Burnel took time out from the Stranglers to fly out to Japan at short notice and join ARB to cover the tour, including appearing at the 'All Japan Rock Festival' at Hibaya park, becoming the first non-Japanese to ever appear at the festival.<ref>Strangled Vol.2 No.18 – June 1984</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qu1WmP0nQMo | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625034804/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qu1WmP0nQMo| archive-date=2014-06-25 | url-status=dead|title=HA・GA・KU・RE ・ ARB with J・J BURNEL(The Stranglers) |publisher=YouTube |access-date=4 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arb-tamashii.com/biography/bio_frame.htm |title=無題ドキュメント |publisher=Arb-tamashii.com |access-date=4 July 2011}}</ref> [[Jean Jacques Burnel|Burnel]] toured with [[ARB (band)|ARB]] for 5 weeks and played on two studio tracks, "Yellow Blood" and "Fight it Out", both of which appeared on the RCA Victor [[ARB (band)|ARB]] album ''Yellow Blood''.<ref>Strangled. Vol: 2. No.: 21. June 1985</ref>

===Second phase (1979–1982)===
In 1979, one of the Stranglers' two managers advised them to break up as he felt that the band had lost direction, but this idea was dismissed and they parted company with their management team.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=135}} Meanwhile, Burnel released an experimental solo album ''[[Euroman Cometh]]'' backed by a small UK tour and Cornwell recorded the album ''[[Nosferatu (Hugh Cornwell and Robert Williams album)|Nosferatu]]'' in collaboration with [[Robert Williams (drummer)|Robert Williams]]. Later that year the Stranglers released ''[[The Raven (The Stranglers album)|The Raven]]'', which heralded a transition towards a more melodic and complex sound which appealed more to the album than the singles market. The songs on ''The Raven'' are multi-layered and musically complicated, and deal with such subjects as a [[Viking]]'s lonely voyage, heroin addiction, genetic engineering, contemporary political events in Iran and Australia and extraterrestrial visitors, [[Men in black|"Meninblack"]]. ''The Raven'' saw a definite transition in the band's sound. The [[Hohner]] [[Cembalet]] – so prominent on the previous three albums – was dropped and [[Oberheim]] synthesizers used instead whilst acoustic piano was used on "Don't Bring Harry". A harmonizer was used to treat Burnel's vocal on the track "Meninblack", the recording of which led to [[Martin Rushent]], who had produced their earlier albums, walking out leaving the band to co-produce the album themselves with [[Alan Winstanley]].{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=131}}   
{{Quotation|We're never going to use a producer again. They are just shitty little parasites. All they're good for is telling jokes. And we know better jokes than any of 'em.|Hugh Cornwell, ''[[NME]]'' – November 1979<ref name="NME Rock 'N' Roll Years">{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Tobler
| year= 1992
| title= NME Rock 'N' Roll Years
| edition= 1st
| publisher=Reed International Books Ltd
| location= London
| page= 332
| id= CN 5585}}</ref>}}

''The Raven'' was not released in the US; instead a compilation album ''[[The Stranglers IV]]'' was released in 1980, containing a selection of tracks from ''The Raven'' and a mix of earlier and later non-album tracks. ''The Raven'' sold well, reaching No.4 in the [[UK Albums Chart]] - it spawned one top 20 single, "[[Duchess (The Stranglers song)|Duchess]]", with "Nuclear Device" reaching No.36 and the [[Extended play|EP]] "Don't Bring Harry" reaching No.41. This was followed by a non-album single, "Bear Cage", backed with "Shah Shah a Go Go" from ''The Raven''. A 12-inch single, the band's first, containing extended mixes of both tracks was also released, but "Bear Cage" also only managed No.36 in the charts.

Following the success of the Stranglers' previous four albums they were given complete freedom for their next, ''[[The Gospel According to the Meninblack]]'', a [[concept album]] exploring religion and the supposed connection between religious phenomena and extraterrestrial visitors. It was preceded by a single "Who Wants the World", which didn't appear on the album, and only just made the top 40. The album also included "Waltzinblack" which became adopted as a theme by TV chef [[Keith Floyd]]. ''The Gospel According to The Meninblack'' was very different from their earlier work and alienated many fans.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=174}} It peaked on the UK albums chart at No.8, their lowest placing to date, and in 1981 was widely considered an artistic and commercial failure.{{sfn|Buckley|1997|page=174}} The track "Two Sunspots" had been recorded during the ''Black And White'' sessions in 1978, but was shelved until 1980 when it was rediscovered and placed on ''The Gospel According to the Meninblack''. The "Meninblack" track from ''The Raven'' is the "Two Sunspots" soundtrack slowed down.{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=131}}

After a slow start, the Stranglers recovered their commercial and critical status with ''[[La folie (album)|La Folie]]'' (1981) which was another concept album, this time exploring the subject of love. At first ''La Folie'' charted lower than any other Stranglers studio album, and the first single taken from it, "Let Me Introduce You to the Family", only charted at No.42. However, the next single was "[[Golden Brown]]". The song is an evocative waltz-time ballad, with an extra beat in the fourth bar. Cornwell said the lyrics were "about heroin and also about a girl. She was of [[Mediterranean]] origin and her skin was golden brown."{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=215}} It became their biggest hit, charting at No.2 in the [[UK Singles Chart]]. It was also named as "record of the week" on [[BBC Radio 2]], despite the station not previously playing music associated with the punk genre. It remains a radio staple to this day. Following this success, ''La Folie'' recharted at No.11 in the UK albums chart.  "[[Tramp (Stranglers song)|Tramp]]" was originally thought to be the ideal follow-up single to "Golden Brown"; however "La Folie" was chosen after Burnel convinced his bandmates of its potential.{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=223}} Sung in French, it received negligible airplay and charted at No.47. Shortly afterwards the Stranglers left EMI. As part of their severance deal, the Stranglers were forced to release a greatest hits collection, ''[[The Collection 1977–1982]]''.{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=217}} The track listing for ''The Collection 1977–1982'' included the new single "[[Strange Little Girl]]", which had originally been recorded on a demo in '74 and rejected by EMI. It became a hit, charting at No.7 in July 1982.

===New label and sound (1983–1990)===
Following the Stranglers' return to commercial success, many record companies lined up to sign them. [[Virgin Records]] was the most likely choice but [[Epic Records]] made a last minute offer and secured the Stranglers' services. The Stranglers once again had complete artistic freedom and in 1983 released their first album for Epic, ''[[Feline (The Stranglers album)|Feline]]'', which included the UK No. 9 hit "[[European Female]]". The album was another change in musical direction, this time influenced by European music. It was the first Stranglers album to feature acoustic guitars, and it was on this album that Jet Black began to use electronic drum kits.{{sfn|Cornwell|Drury|2001|page=227}} Hugh Cornwell stated, "On ''La Folie'' there were three tracks – 'Golden Brown' ... 'La Folie' and 'How to Find True Love and Happiness in the Present Day' – that sort of pointed us away from what we had been doing. It was strange doing those tracks, because we'd never really attempted that quite minimalistic recording technique. And when we started writing for ''Feline'', things were coming out the same way."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Burton|first=Nick |title=Lean and Hungry Stranglers Protest the High-Tech Age|journal=Record|date=June 1983|volume=2 |issue=8|page=8}}</ref> The album gained much critical success but fell well short of ''La Folie'' in terms of sales and failed to produce another hit after "European Female". Nonetheless ''Feline'' broke the Stranglers in Europe and reached No.4 in the UK chart in January 1983.

1984 saw the release of ''[[Aural Sculpture]]'' which consolidated the band's success in Europe and established them in [[Oceania]]. It included the UK No.15 hit "[[Aural Sculpture|Skin Deep]]" (which also reached No. 11 in Australia and No. 19 in New Zealand, and Top 30 in the Netherlands). This was their first album to feature the three-piece horn-section which was retained in all their subsequent albums and live performances until Hugh Cornwell's departure in 1990. ''Aural Sculpture'' was only a moderate success in the UK album charts, peaking at No.14 in November 1984.

Their 1986 album, ''[[Dreamtime (The Stranglers album)|Dreamtime]]'', dealt with environmental concerns among other issues. Its signature track, and another radio staple for many years to come, was "[[Always the Sun]]" (a No.15 hit in France and No.16 hit in Ireland, No.21 in Australia, No.30 in the UK, and No.42 in the Netherlands). The only Stranglers album to chart in the US, ''Dreamtime'' was again only a moderate hit in the UK, reaching No. 16 in November 1986.

The Stranglers' final album with Cornwell, ''[[10 (The Stranglers album)|10]]'', was released in 1990. This was recorded with the intention of building on their "cult" status in America. Following the success of their cover of [[The Kinks]]' "[[All Day and All of the Night]]", a UK No. 7 hit in 1988, the Stranglers released another '60s cover, "[[96 Tears]]" as their first single from ''10''; it reached No. 17 in the UK. Despite this success, the follow-up single "Sweet Smell of Success" only reached No.65. "Man of the Earth", which the band had high hopes for, was due to be the third single from the album, however Epic Records decided against it. In August 1990, Hugh Cornwell abruptly left Stranglers to pursue a solo career, following the band's failure to attain a tour in the US.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cornwell |first1=Hugh |title=A Multitude of Sins |date=2005 |publisher=Harper Collins |isbn=978-0-00733356-1 |page=17}}</ref> In his autobiography, Cornwell stated that he felt that the Stranglers were a spent force creatively, and cited various examples of his increasingly acrimonious relationship with his fellow band-members, particularly Burnel.

===Post-Cornwell era (1990s)===
Following the departure of Cornwell, CBS-Sony dropped Stranglers from their roster. The remaining members recruited [[John Ellis (guitarist)|John Ellis]], who had had a long-standing association with the band. He had opened for them in the 1970s as a member of [[The Vibrators]], filled in for Cornwell during his time in prison for drug possession in 1980, worked with Burnel and Greenfield in their side-project Purple Helmets, and been added to the Stranglers' line-up as a touring guitarist a short time before Cornwell's departure. Burnel and Ellis briefly took over vocal duties (for one television appearance on ''[[The Word (TV series)|The Word]]'') before enlisting [[Paul Roberts (musician)|Paul Roberts]], who sang on most songs live, even those originally sung by Burnel.

This line-up recorded four albums: ''[[Stranglers in the Night]]'' (1992), ''[[About Time (The Stranglers album)|About Time]]'' (1995), ''[[Written in Red]]'' (1997) and ''[[Coup de Grace (The Stranglers album)|Coup de Grace]]'' (1998).

===2000s resurgence and reversion to a four-piece===
In 2000, Ellis left the band and a new guitarist, [[Baz Warne]], was recruited.

The Stranglers achieved something of a critical and popular renaissance in 2004<ref>{{cite web |last1=Peacock |first1=Tim |title=The Old Testament: The UA Studio Recordings 1977-1982|url=https://recordcollectormag.com/reviews/album/the-old-testament-the-ua-studio-recordings-1977-1982 |website=Record Collector |publisher=Diamond Publishing |access-date=8 October 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Ian |title=The Stranglers, Salisbury City Hall |url=https://www.dailyecho.co.uk/leisure/music/10319941.the-stranglers-salisbury-city-hall/ |website=The Daily Echo |publisher=Newsquest Media |access-date=8 October 2021}}</ref> with the album ''[[Norfolk Coast (album)|Norfolk Coast]]'' and a subsequent sell-out tour, together with their first Top-40 hit (No. 31 UK) in fourteen years, "[[Big Thing Coming]]". The album also included ''Tuckers Grave'' about a Somerset cider house named after the victim of a suicide in a nearby farm which members of the band now occupied. In 2005, ''Coast to Coast: Live on Tour'' was released, the live album contained songs recorded during their tour the previous year. On their sellout UK tour they were supported by [[Goldblade]].

In May 2006, Roberts left the band, and the Stranglers were now back to a four-piece line-up: Burnel, Black, Greenfield and Warne, with the lead vocals shared between Warne and Burnel. In concert, Burnel returned to singing the songs he originally recorded as lead vocalist, and Warne sang the numbers originally led by Hugh Cornwell.

''[[Suite XVI]]'', the follow-up album to ''Norfolk Coast'', was released in September 2006 (the title is a pun on "Sweet 16" and also a reference to the fact that it was the band's sixteenth studio album) and continued the band's resurgence. Although partly a return to the band's heavier punk roots, the album featured a typically idiosyncratic mixture of musical styles which included a country and western style Johnny Cash pastiche/homage "I Hate You".

In 2007 it was reported that drummer Black was suffering from [[atrial fibrillation]], an ailment which subsequently forced him to miss a number of shows, particularly where extended travel was required. On such occasions Ian Barnard, Black's drum technician, deputised.<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.stranglers.net/n_arch_27.html
 |title       = SIS News Archive – A Message from Jet Black
 |publisher   = Stranglers.net
 |access-date  = 16 February 2009
 |url-status     = dead
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716144839/http://www.stranglers.net/n_arch_27.html
 |archive-date = 16 July 2011
 |df          = dmy-all
}}</ref>

On 4 November 2007, the band (with Black) played a sell-out gig at the [[Roundhouse (venue)|Roundhouse]] in [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]], North London, marking the thirtieth anniversary of their headline run at the same venue in 1977. The set list was the same as the 1977 concert, with the addition of a couple of more recent songs as a final encore. The event is recorded on the DVD ''[[Rattus at the Roundhouse]]''.<ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.stranglers.net/n_arch_29.html
 |title       = SIS News Archive
 |publisher   = Stranglers.net
 |access-date  = 16 February 2009
 |url-status     = dead
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716144922/http://www.stranglers.net/n_arch_29.html
 |archive-date = 16 July 2011
 |df          = dmy-all
}}</ref>

===2010–present===
The Stranglers continued their resurgence in 2010 starting with an extensive UK tour, including a sold-out return to the Hammersmith Apollo in March, their first visit there since 1987. They were supported on the 16-date UK tour by [[Max raptor|Max Raptor]].<ref name="SIS News">{{cite web
|url = http://www.stranglers.net/News_18.html
|title = SIS News
|publisher=Stranglers.net
|access-date = 8 April 2010
}}</ref>

A double CD [[compilation album]], ''Decades Apart'', containing a selection of tracks from the full career of the band, including at least one from each of their sixteen studio albums and two new tracks, "Retro Rockets" and "I Don't See the World Like You Do", was released in February 2010. The download version of ''Decades Apart'' included an unreleased recording from 1978, "Wasting Time", inspired by the band's 'Rock Goes To College' experience earlier that year;<ref name="rgtc" /> this track, originally titled "Social Secs" was never released, and the music ended up being reversed and released as "Yellowcake UF6", the B-side to "Nuclear Device" in 1979.

Across the summer the band played a number of festivals, including [[Weyfest]] and [[Glastonbury Festival|Glastonbury]] and [[T in the Park]] in the UK and [[Oxegen 2010]] in Ireland, and concerts in Japan, Greece, Poland, Slovakia and Bulgaria. The band also released a new live album and DVD, recorded at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in May 2010.<ref name="SIS News"/> In March 2011, the band completed another UK tour. Burnel's long-term friend, [[Wilko Johnson]], was invited to bring The Wilko Johnson band on the tour. In April, the band began touring Europe, with many gigs and major festivals lined up for the entire year.

[[File:Jim MacAulay.JPG|right|thumb|Jim Macaulay, the touring drummer, in 2013]]
On 23 September 2012, the band returned to [[Looe]], Cornwall, fronted by Warne and Burnel. The band had originally spent time in Looe writing ''Suite XVI''.<ref name="This is Cornwall">{{cite web
|url = http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/Stranglers-Baz-Warne-talks-Lee-Trewhela-punk/story-16894291-detail/story.html|title = SIS News|publisher=Stranglers.net
|access-date = 14 September 2012
}}</ref>

''[[Giants (The Stranglers album)|Giants]]'' was released in 2012, including the first [[instrumental]] on an album since "Waltzinblack" on ''The Gospel According to The Meninblack''. The "deluxe" version consisted of a second disc containing tracks from the 'Weekend in Black' acoustic session in November 2011.

2013 saw the band play a full UK tour, with Black playing the second half at most gigs (Jim Macaulay taking the first half).<ref>{{cite news | first = Martin | last = Hutchinson | title = Live Review: The Stranglers – Manchester Academy – 30/3/2013 | publisher = [[The Bolton News]] | date = 1 April 2013 | url = http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/leisure/boltonmusic/music_reviews/10326080.Live_Review__The_Stranglers___Manchester_Academy___30_3_2013/ | access-date = 11 June 2013}}</ref> Several festivals were booked for 2013, including a session at the [[BBC Proms]] on 12 August. For the North American tour Black was not present, with Macaulay playing the entire show.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thestranglers.net/?p=6117 | title = Summer Drummer | date = 19 June 2012 | publisher = thestranglers.net | access-date = 11 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Belinda | last = Goldsmith | title = Stranglers break out of punk mould with classical and ballet | date = 24 April 2013 | work = Reuters | url = http://in.reuters.com/article/music-stranglers-idINDEE93N0CO20130424 | access-date = 11 June 2013}}</ref>

In 2014, the band celebrated their fortieth birthday with a Ruby Tour, throughout the UK and Europe. In 2015, the March On tour had 18 dates around the United Kingdom. Where stage space allowed, a second drum kit was set up and Jet Black appeared for a set of four songs. A proposed gig in Moscow was announced and then cancelled due to visa difficulties, but a mini-tour of the UK took place in  July. The band then played gigs throughout Europe, ending in November. In April 2016, they returned to New Zealand and Australia.<ref>{{cite web|author=Walter Marsh |url=http://ripitup.com.au/music/the-stranglers-announce-2016-australian-tour#.Vw9sfPl97IU |title=The Stranglers announce 2016 Australian tour |publisher=Rip It Up |date=26 August 2015 |access-date=14 April 2016}}</ref>

Black has not performed on stage with the band since partial-set appearances in March 2015, although he remained an official member of the band until his retirement was confirmed in 2018. Jim Macaulay appeared in a promotional photograph alongside Burnel, Greenfield and Warne for the first time in 2016 and has since been named as an official member of the group.

In August 2017, the Stranglers performed at an outdoor concert in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] as part of the [[UK City of Culture]] celebrations. In July 2018, the band played at the LUNAR festival in [[Tanworth-in-Arden]].

During an interview with [[Janice Long]], on [[BBC Radio Wales]], on 10 July 2018, Burnel revealed that Black continued to be in fairly poor health and had suffered a minor stroke earlier in 2018.

Greenfield died on 3 May 2020, at the age of 71. He had contracted [[COVID-19]] while in hospital for a heart ailment.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stranglers keyboard player dies with coronavirus |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-52537293 |website=BBC News |access-date=4 May 2020 |date=4 May 2020}}</ref> The band's eighteenth studio album ''[[Dark Matters (The Stranglers album)|Dark Matters]]'', features contributions from Greenfield and is also their first release following the retirement of Jet Black.<ref name=robbdarkmatters /> It was released on 10 September 2021,<ref name="Dark Matters">{{cite web |title=Dark Matters |url=https://stranglers.tmstor.es/product/79632 |website=The Stranglers |access-date=29 June 2021}}</ref> and entered the UK album chart at number 4, the highest position since ''Feline'' in 1983 and their first top 10 position since 1990.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Copsey |first1=Rob |title=Manic Street Preachers win "titanic battle" against Steps to claim second Number 1 on Official Albums Chart |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/manic-street-preachers-win-titanic-battle-against-steps-to-claim-second-number-1-on-official-albums-chart__34059/ |website=Official Charts |publisher=The Official UK Charts Company |access-date=18 September 2021}}</ref>

In November 2021, the band began their last full tour with their new keyboard player, Toby Hounsham, who played with [[Rialto_(band)|Rialto]], an English rock band formed in London in 1997, and subsequently [[Mungo Jerry]] for live and studio work since the early 2000s.  The tour is currently scheduled to continue through the UK and several European countries, ending in Sweden in October 2022.

==Legacy==

"[[No More Heroes (The Stranglers song)|No More Heroes]]" was featured in the first episode of the [[BBC]] series ''[[Ashes to Ashes (British TV series)|Ashes to Ashes]]'' and in the third episode of the second season of the American TV show ''[[Queer as Folk (2000 TV series)|Queer as Folk]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://princessofbabylon.com/songlist.html#203%20/ |title=Queer as Folk Music |publisher=Princessofbabylon.com |access-date=21 May 2013}}</ref> The title was used for the 2007 video game ''[[No More Heroes (video game)|No More Heroes]]'', created by Japanese designer [[Goichi Suda]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Boyes |first1=Emma |title=Q&A: SUDA-51 on No More Heroes |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/qanda-suda-51-on-no-more-heroes/1100-6184857/ |website=Gamespot |publisher=CBS Interactive |access-date=25 October 2018}}</ref> who is also a fan of the band.<ref name='eightandahalfbit'>{{cite web |title=The Bizarre and Brilliant Video Game World of Goichi Suda|website=Eight And A Half Bit|publisher=Eight And A Half Bit|date=8 February 2013|url=https://eightandahalfbit.com/2013/02/08/the-bizarre-and-brilliant-video-game-world-of-goichi-suda/|access-date=21 March 2022}}</ref> Despite the name, the cost of licensing the track prevented the song from appearing in the game.<ref name='eightandahalfbit' /> A cover version by [[Violent Femmes]] was used for the film ''[[Mystery Men]]''.

The song "Let me Down Easy" was used as the opening credits theme for [[Hardcore Henry]]. "[[Peaches (The Stranglers song)|Peaches]]" appeared in the title sequence of ''[[Sexy Beast]]'' by director [[Jonathan Glazer]], and was used as the closing theme for many of [[Keith Floyd]]'s cooking programmes, with the instrumental track 'Waltzinblack' providing the title music.

"[[Golden Brown]]" featured in [[Guy Ritchie]]'s film ''[[Snatch (film)|Snatch]]'' (2000), was used extensively in the Australian film ''[[He Died with a Felafel in His Hand (film)|He Died with a Felafel in His Hand]]''. It also featured in the ''[[Black Mirror]]'' episode "[[Metalhead (Black Mirror)|Metalhead]]"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hooton |first1=Christopher |last2=Stolworthy |first2=Jacob |title=Netflix's Black Mirror season 4: Every episode ranked |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/netflix-black-mirror-season-4-review-ranked-uss-callister-arkangel-hang-the-dj-crocodile-back-museum-a8133676.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220620/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/netflix-black-mirror-season-4-review-ranked-uss-callister-arkangel-hang-the-dj-crocodile-back-museum-a8133676.html |archive-date=20 June 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |website=The Independent |date=30 December 2017 |publisher=Independent Print Limited |access-date=25 October 2018}}</ref> and in Season 2 of ''[[The_Umbrella_Academy_(TV_series)|The Umbrella Academy]]''.{{citation needed|date=January 2022}}

More songs by the Stranglers have been licensed for use in commercials than from any other punk band.<ref name='oxford'>{{cite book |title=The Oxford Handbook of Music and Advertising|author1=James Deaville|author2=Siu-Lan Tan|author3=Ron Rodman|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=18 January 2021|isbn=978-0-19-069127-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WPUTEAAAQBAJ&pg=PA466|access-date=21 March 2022}}</ref> "Always The Sun" was used for a tv and radio campaign by insurance company [[Sun Alliance (company)|Sun Alliance]] in 1992 and 1993.<ref name='sunaliiance'>{{cite magazine |title=Always The Sun Alliance!|magazine=Strangled|issue=37|publisher=Stranglers Information Service|date=1992|page=4|url=https://archive.org/details/strangled-vol-2-no-37-1992/page/4/mode/2up|access-date=21 March 2022}}</ref> "Peaches" has appeared on adverts for [[Adidas]], [[HSBC]], [[Tesco]] and [[JBL]] speakers<ref name='oxford' /> while "Waltzinblack" has been used for [[Vodafone]] and the [[Carphone Warehouse]].<ref name='oxford' /> In 2002 "[[Hanging Around (The Stranglers song)|Hanging Around]]", a track from the 1977 debut album ''Rattus Norvegicus'' which was never released as a single, was used in several French [[Wonderbra]] commercials<ref name='oxford' /> featuring model [[Inna Zobova]].<ref name='dailymotion'>{{cite web |title=Inna Zobova in Wonderbra|website=Dailymotion|publisher=Dailymotion|date=2011|url=https://www.dailymotion.com/eg/topic/x1mq11|access-date=21 March 2022}}</ref> "Golden Brown" was used to advertise [[Ore-Ida]] french fries and later used in [[Waitrose]]'s 2008 Christmas campaign.<ref name='oxford' />

[[Tori Amos]] covered "[[Strange Little Girl]]" on her 2001 ''[[Strange Little Girls]]'' album.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/strange-little-girls-mw0000011921 |title=Strange Little Girls – Tori Amos | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |website=AllMusic |date=18 September 2001 |access-date=23 March 2014}}</ref>

==Members==

'''Current members'''
* [[Jean-Jacques Burnel]] – bass, backing vocals <small>(1974–present)</small>, lead vocals <small>(1974–1990, 2006–present)</small>
* [[Baz Warne]] – guitar, backing vocals <small>(2000–present)</small>, lead vocals <small>(2006–present)</small>
* Jim Macaulay – drums, percussion, backing vocals <small>(2018–present, touring musician: 2012–2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Carne |first1=Owen |title=News: Summer drummer… |url=https://thestranglers.co.uk/summer-drummer/ |website=thestranglers.co.uk |date=19 June 2012|access-date=28 January 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Jim Macaulay: Biog |url=https://www.jimmacaulaydrums.com/biog |website=jimmacaulaydrums.com |access-date=28 January 2022}}</ref></small>
* Toby Hounsham – keyboards, backing vocals <small>(2021-present)</small>
'''Former members'''
* [[Jet Black]] – drums, percussion <small>(1974–2018)<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nerssessian |first1=Joe |title=The Stranglers: All the things we did that were frowned upon in the past now seem like badges of honour |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/the-stranglers-all-the-things-we-did-that-were-frowned-upon-in-the-past-now-seem-like-badges-of-honour-36656159.html |newspaper=Belfasttelegraph |publisher=Mediahuis |access-date=25 August 2021}}</ref></small>
* [[Hugh Cornwell]] – guitar, lead and backing vocals <small>(1974–1990)</small>
* [[Hans Wärmling]] – keyboards, backing vocals, guitar <small>(1974–1975; died 1995)</small>
* [[Dave Greenfield]] – keyboards, backing vocals, occasional lead vocals <small>(1975–2020; died 2020)</small>
* [[John Ellis (guitarist)|John Ellis]] – guitar, backing vocals <small>(1990–2000)</small>
* [[Paul Roberts (musician)|Paul Roberts]] – lead vocals <small>(1990–2006)</small>

'''Former touring musicians'''
* Ian Barnard – drums, percussion <small>(2007–2012)</small>

<small>(In the late 1980s, the Stranglers regularly featured a 3-piece brass section in their live line-up.)</small>
